channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: What would your computer say about you? Perl, Python, NLP role in Amsterdam
item.description: Our client is the worldwide leader in machine intelligence for matching people with jobs, which is to say that when it comes to hiring, they know what they’re doing. Applicants, bring your “A” game: they’re looking for a Natural Language Processing (NLP) Engineer who is passionate about Machine Intelligence and can evaluate NLP systems.

item.title: Music-loving DevOps (with Perl), get in here! London based role
item.description: We’ve got an intriguing role for a Lead DevOps Engineer who cares about great music. As an independent global music business, our client works with artists, labels, and distributors to release and sell music on their digital platform. They’ve got their own private cloud located in London and with offices in London and Shoreditch, you’ve got options on where to set up shop.

item.title: Python and Perl: Better Together! Perl/Python role in London
item.description: Where better for a multi-talented developer like you than an organization at apex of their field? These premium native advertising gurus understand corporate, tech, financial services, and lifestyle technology. They are looking for a Senior Developer skilled in both Perl and Python.

item.title: Good (Perl) Humans Wanted. Remote Perl role in USA
item.description: Most jobs get you paid, but the best ones help you make the world a better place. To increase your karmic bank account while adding dollars and cents at your financial institution, we’ve found a 100% remote role that will let you make a difference from the comfort of your living room.

item.title: Are you at the head of the pack? Chief Software Architect role in Malaysia (or remote)
item.description: You’ve done your time in the trenches. Long hours, late nights, a steep learning curve, and now you have the experience to lead. Sharing your expertise is the natural next step; you want a role where you can make a real difference and have a tangible impact on day-to-day operations.

item.title: Boston Perl Mongers Online Meeting - topic TBD or round-table
item.description: Tuesday April 12th, 2021 07:00 PM Eastern Time (US and Canada)

item.title: Bericht Deutscher Perl/Raku-Workshop 2022
item.description: About the Perl-Raku Workshop in German

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Farey and Moebius
item.description: This week, we got the glimpse of JavaScript. What a treat, thank you for everything.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 159
item.description: A complex one-liner in Perl as always. Thanks for your support and contributions.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 159: numbers and numbers
item.description: Luca has been sharing Raku magic for years now. This week was no different, a very compact solution. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 159: Farey Sequence and Möbius Number
item.description: It's treat to see rational data type Rat in action. Thanks for sharing Raku and Perl magic with us.

item.title: PWC159 - Moebius Number
item.description: Raku method name with Unicode character. Really cool, never seen before. Thanks for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: PWC159 - Farey Sequence
item.description: Use of method signature in Perl solution makes it very similar to Raku. It would be nice to see it become part of core Perl. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge 159
item.description: A very thorough solution, like every week. I wish I could do the same complete with performance matrix. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Métal Perlant
item.description: To be honest, I enjoy the introduction more than the solution itself. Solution is self explanatory, thanks for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: Squarefree Is Only One Side Of the Story
item.description: Loved the Raku version more than the Perl. You don't want to miss the story around the task. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Fareys Wear Boots
item.description: After a long time, seen Moo based package solution. It makes code so clean. Just loved it. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: CY's Take on The Weekly Challenge #159
item.description: Cheok-Yin doesn't blog regularly but every time she does, we get a treat. I really enjoy behind the scene story. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Farey, Moebius and Raku
item.description: Arne used the power of Raku to the extreme and present us cool solutions. Thanks for your contributions as always.

item.title: Farey and Farey Again, but in a Mobius Way
item.description: The Adam's blog Notes section sharing very interesting aspects of the task. Highly recommended.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 159
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Farey Sequence" and "Moebius Number" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 160
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Four Is Magic" and "Equilibrium Index". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: List of new CPAN distributions – Feb 2022
List of new CPAN distributions – Mar 2022
The ordering operators
item.description: When Aristotle writes: "Perl has two operators, cmp and <=>, which are basically never seen outside of sort blocks. That doesn't mean you can't use them elsewhere, though." I think oh-oh, here comes the scary part :-)

item.title: Perl Advent Calendar articles about Moose
item.description: A collection of links to the articles.

item.title: #559 - Endangered and dying languages
item.description:
Hi!

While the population of the world is growing the language-diversity is shrinking. There are many languages that are used less and less. (Wikipedia has a list by location. I am sure as programmers there are plenty of thing we can also do to help. That's why I have been investing time in LibreLingo project and specifically in Judaeo-Spanish (aka. Ladino, or Judezmo). Now I can also show you the dictionary I have been working on. You can type in words in any of the languages listed there and it will try to find the Ladino word for it. The dictionary is still small. It contains only 3,500 words, but I hope I'll be able to enlarge it to help people who would like to learn Ladino.

It was a very slow week and I hardly found any articles to include (besides the Weekly Challenge that Mohammad collects), but there were also new authors. Let me congratulate to Julien Fiegehenn and Scotticles for their first posts.

Enjoy your week!
